name: 臺灣政治社會史專題
description: 本課程介紹史前迄今的臺灣歷史中的重要課題，協助學生以歷史的角度理解臺灣在社會與政治上的階段性變化，亦意在刺激學生思考臺灣在世界史中的定位。本課以英語講授，課程之進行方式將包括兩小時講授與一小時對指定閱讀之課堂討論或小組報告；建議學生應有基本英語聽說讀寫能力，能有中文閱讀能力更佳。
goals: To understand the major social and political shifts of Taiwan society
To read English literatures about Taiwan history
To explore and enquire into pervasively-discussed historical issues and their connection with contemporary Taiwan society
syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to the course

Week 2: Students self-introduction and introduction to methodology, research tools and required knowledge in understanding Taiwan history

Week 3: Taiwan and the Austronesian world

Week 4: The “Emergence” of Taiwan History

Week 5: Legacy of the Dutch, Spaniard and others in the Seventeenth Century

Week 6: Konxiga and the Chinese regime on Taiwan

Week 7: The Beginning of Taiwan as a part of the Chinese Empire

Week 8: Land and social development of Taiwan under Qing rule

Week 9: Mid-term examination week

Week 10: The end of the Chinese imperial regimen on Taiwan

Week 11: Modernisation and the new Japanese rule

Week 12: Foreign presence and development on the island of Taiwan

Week 13: Taiwan in the “Japanese Empire” during WWII

Week 14: The “back” of the Chinese regime: political and social transformation

Week 15: Taiwan ‘s democratization: cinema appreciation – _Hand in Hand_ (2011, 140 mins) or a class trip to Nylon Cheng Memorial Museum

Week 16: Taiwan’s identity crisis and grass-root social movements

Week 17: Taiwan in modern world

Week 18: Term examination week

grading.note: Submission of a term essay under a word limit of 3,500. It should highlight students’ personal experiences, reading endeavor and systematical thinking of Taiwan history. Can be presented in forms of case study report, short movie, exhibition or others. Grades will be given upon the originality and logical thinking on students’ finding and thoughts about Taiwan history. Students are advised to make appointments to discuss with the teacher.
A critic essay on one of the references listed below, not to exceed the limit of 1,000 word.
Personal self-introduction / presentation / group presentation, and involvement in class discussion.
